sections.title: What are conditionals?
sections.content:
**Conditionals** are sentences with an **if-clause** (condition) and a **main clause** (result). The tenses we use depend on how **real** or **unreal** the situation is.

• **Zero:** general truths, facts (always true)
• **First:** real future (possible)
• **Second:** unreal or hypothetical present/future
• **Third:** unreal past (something that did not happen)

sections.title: Zero conditional
sections.content:
**If + present simple**, **present simple** (in both clauses).

Used for **general truths**, **facts**, **scientific facts**, **habits**:

• If you **heat** ice, it **melts**.
• If you **mix** red and blue, you **get** purple.
• If I **don't sleep** well, I **feel** tired.

**When** can replace **if** when we mean "whenever": When you heat water to 100°C, it boils.

sections.title: First conditional
sections.content:
**If + present simple**, **will + base verb** (or other future forms: going to, can, must, imperative).

Used for **real future** situations – possible or likely:

• If it **rains** tomorrow, I **will stay** at home.
• If you **finish** early, **call** me. (imperative)
• If we **don't hurry**, we **will miss** the bus.

We do **not** use **will** in the if-clause: Wrong: *If I will see him …* Right: **If I see him**, I will tell him.

sections.title: Second conditional
sections.content:
**If + past simple**, **would + base verb**.

Used for **unreal** or **hypothetical** present or future – imagined, unlikely or impossible:

• If I **had** more time, I **would help** you. (I don't have more time.)
• If I **were** you, I **would apologise**. (I'm not you; *were* is used for all persons in formal style.)
• If we **won** the lottery, we **would travel** the world. (Unlikely.)

**Could** and **might** are also possible: If he tried harder, he **could** pass. We do **not** use **would** in the if-clause: Wrong: *If I would have time …* Right: **If I had** time …

sections.title: Third conditional
sections.content:
**If + past perfect**, **would have + past participle**.

Used for **unreal past** – something that **did not happen** (we imagine a different past):

• If I **had known**, I **would have told** you. (I didn't know.)
• If she **had left** earlier, she **would have caught** the train. (She didn't leave earlier.)
• If they **hadn't missed** the flight, they **would have arrived** on time.

We do **not** use **would have** in the if-clause: Wrong: *If I would have known …* Right: **If I had known** …

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• **Zero:** if + present, present → facts, general truths (If you heat ice, it melts.)
• **First:** if + present, will + base → real future (If it rains, I will stay home.)
• **Second:** if + past, would + base → unreal present/future (If I had time, I would help.)
• **Third:** if + past perfect, would have + past participle → unreal past (If I had known, I would have told you.)
• Never use **will** or **would** in the **if-clause** (only in the main clause for first/second/third).

sections.title: Typical learner errors
sections.content:
• **Will in if-clause:** Wrong: *If I will see him, I'll tell him.* Right: **If I see him**, I'll tell him. (First conditional: present in if-clause.)
• **Would in if-clause (second):** Wrong: *If I would have time, I would help.* Right: **If I had time**, I would help.
• **Would have in if-clause (third):** Wrong: *If I would have known, I would have come.* Right: **If I had known**, I would have come.
• **Mixing second and third:** Wrong: *If I had known, I would tell you.* (Past condition, but present result – use third: **I would have told** you.)
• **Was vs were (second):** In formal style we use **If I were**, **if he were** (subjunctive). In informal speech **was** is common: If I was/were you …

questions.question: Which type of conditional is: 'If you heat water to 100°C, it boils.'?
questions.explanation: Zero conditional: present + present for general/scientific facts.

questions.question: Choose the correct first conditional.

options.a: If it will rain, we will stay at home.
options.b: If it rained, we would stay at home.
options.c: If it rains, we will stay at home.
options.d: If it rains, we would stay at home.

questions.explanation: First conditional: if + present, will + base. No 'will' in the if-clause.

questions.question: 'If I _____ you, I would apologise.' (Second conditional)
questions.explanation: Second conditional: if + past. 'Were' is used for all persons in formal style (subjunctive).

questions.question: Which is a third conditional?

options.a: If I know, I will tell you.
options.b: If I had known, I would tell you.
options.c: If I knew, I would have told you.
options.d: If I had known, I would have told you.

questions.explanation: Third conditional: if + past perfect, would have + past participle (unreal past).

questions.question: What is wrong? 'If I would have time, I would help you.'

options.a: We must use 'had' in the if-clause, not 'would have'.
options.b: We must use 'will' in the main clause.
options.c: We must use past perfect in both clauses.

questions.explanation: Second conditional: if-clause uses past simple (if I had time), not would have.

questions.question: 'If she _____ earlier, she would have caught the train.' (Third conditional)
questions.explanation: Third conditional: if + past perfect (had left).

questions.question: Zero: If you heat ice, it _____.
answers: melts
questions.explanation: Zero conditional: present + present for facts.

questions.question: First: If it _____ tomorrow, we will stay at home.
answers: rains
questions.explanation: First: if + present (rains), will in main clause.

questions.question: Second: If I _____ (have) more time, I would help you.
answers: had
questions.explanation: Second conditional: if + past simple.

questions.question: Second: If I were you, I _____ (apologise).
answers: would apologise
questions.explanation: Second: would + base in main clause.

questions.question: Third: If I _____ (know), I would have told you.
answers: had known
questions.explanation: Third conditional: if + past perfect.

questions.question: Third: If she had left earlier, she _____ (catch) the train.
answers: would have caught
questions.explanation: Third: would have + past participle in main clause.

questions.question: First: If you _____ early, call me.
answers: finish
questions.explanation: First: if + present; main clause can be imperative.

questions.question: Zero: If you don't sleep well, you _____ tired.
answers: feel
questions.explanation: Zero: present in both clauses.

questions.question: Second: If we _____ (win) the lottery, we would travel the world.
answers: won
questions.explanation: Second: if + past simple (won, not would win).

questions.question: Third: If they hadn't missed the flight, they _____ (arrive) on time.
answers: would have arrived
questions.explanation: Third: would have + past participle.

questions.question: Wrong: 'If I will see him, I'll tell him.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If I see him, I'll tell him.
If I see him, I'll tell him
questions.explanation: First conditional: no 'will' in the if-clause; use present.

questions.question: Wrong: 'If I would have time, I would help.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If I had time, I would help.
If I had time, I would help
questions.explanation: Second conditional: if-clause uses past simple (had), not would have.

questions.question: Wrong: 'If I would have known, I would have come.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If I had known, I would have come.
If I had known, I would have come
questions.explanation: Third conditional: if-clause uses past perfect (had known), not would have.

questions.question: Wrong: 'If I had known, I would tell you.' (Meaning: I didn't know, so I didn't tell.) Correct the sentence.
answers: If I had known, I would have told you.
If I had known, I would have told you
questions.explanation: Third conditional: both clauses refer to the past – would have told.

questions.question: Wrong: 'If it will rain, we will stay at home.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If it rains, we will stay at home.
If it rains, we will stay at home
questions.explanation: First conditional: present in if-clause (if it rains).

questions.question: Wrong: 'If she had left earlier, she would catch the train.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If she had left earlier, she would have caught the train.
If she had left earlier, she would have caught the train
questions.explanation: Third conditional: main clause needs would have + past participle.

questions.question: Wrong: 'If you heat water to 100°C, it will boil.' (General fact.) Correct to zero conditional.
answers: If you heat water to 100°C, it boils.
If you heat water to 100°C, it boils
questions.explanation: Zero conditional for general truth: present + present (it boils).

questions.question: Wrong: 'If he would try harder, he could pass.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If he tried harder, he could pass.
If he tried harder, he could pass
questions.explanation: Second conditional: if-clause uses past simple (tried), not would try.
